bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Hannah Whitman Heyde to Walt Whitman, March 15 [1892]
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

body.p:
Only write a line my dear darling brother thinking maybe to daytoday you feel a little better can only hope & hope you may. I think of you morning noon and night, would like to write every day to you but are going to wait till you get better. wellWell enough dear dear brother to sit up, in your chair again & that will be such good news to hear
your letters & the money you send all comes safely.— but your writing to me now—there isare no words to say & I wontwon't try. youYou are the only one in the whole world, would be, so good to me. —
What does me good or what is a comfort to me is nothing, you, are the one I care for my darling.
veryVery many ask after you. DrDr. Bingham says no one has as many friends, & said he wished he was where he could do something for you although he knew you had everything.
It seems as if I could not help writing to day kept thinking of you last night & this morning but I must not tire you if I could only do a bit of good—
wantWant to send much much love, & I do feel for you my dear dear brother.—
Lou has been kind about writing —C. yesterday sold (without frame) picture for $15. may sell more if takes price offered — sold one before some weeks ago., same price
I thank you brother dear for sending me so much money—you are wonderful good to me.

closer.salute: I pray you may be gaining a little by now,—love always
